practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase builds the essential physical callouses and finger independence you need to navigate basic open chords without looking at your hands.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Metronome-synced transitions between CAGED open chords
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Single-string major scale patterns and finger dexterity drills

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Playing individual notes and slow, isolated chord shapes
difficulty_profile.challenging: Switching between C, G, and D chords at 80 BPM without missed strings

objective: Successfully complete 60 chord changes per minute
Consistent clean tone on all six strings for E-major and A-minor
subjective: Decreased physical tension in the fretting hand
Increased confidence in finding the 'home' position on the neck

practice_cycles.focus_summary: Barre chord endurance and rhythmic subdivision
practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase moves you beyond the 'nut' of the guitar so your playing can eventually cover the entire fretboard through movable shapes.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: E-shape and A-shape barre chord transitions across various frets
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Introduction to 8th note strumming patterns and basic ear training

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Maintaining a steady 4/4 strumming pattern on open chords
difficulty_profile.challenging: Maintaining clean barre chord pressure for an entire 3-minute song

objective: Zero buzz on barre chords at the 5th and 7th frets
Accurately identifying major vs minor intervals by ear
subjective: Feeling that the fretboard is becoming 'one' map rather than isolated boxes

objective: BPM milestones for standard scale runs
Error rate in blind chord positioning
subjective: Quality of tone and clarity of articulation
Level of frustration during new material introduction
Physical ease and lack of strain during complex movements

architect_notes: The 3-hour weekly commitment is low for an expert-level target; the timeline to mastery will be multi-year.
Emphasis is placed on consistency over intensity to mitigate the high dropout risk.
Focusing on core mechanics first prevents the accumulation of technical debt that often stalls beginners.

practice_logs.activity: Metronome-synced transitions between CAGED open chords
